item.title: Numbers, Numbers Everywhere
item.description:
Have you ever thought why, as a child, we all love to count and yet, not all of us grow up to love math?

I do not know whether both my kids will later find math frustrating or interesting. I guess first, some sets of milestones have to be reached (Just because a child can count, it doesn’t mean he knows math.). All I can tell is that, just like any other kids, my kids like counting. The big brother beamed when he first figured out how to count from 1 to 10. The little one, well… he skips “One!” and stops at “Two!” for now. That spark of interest… is good enough for me. I don’t expect them to be a mathematician when they grow up.

While personal interest may seem like a good explanation (just like why some prefer dancing to singing, painting to sports, etc.), I do believe that having a good learning companion does matter. I consider myself lucky that I grow up with two big brothers who mysteriously make math fun and interesting. Looking back, I’m pretty amazed at how they could show me how math connects to many interesting things (yeah, I’m still wondering why none of them end up being a teacher!). Math genius? I have no clue - I never check their test scores…hee hee… _seriously, I didn’t bother back then!_ But I’m pretty sure they’re both well-read… :)

Anyway… back to counting (We’ll do math next time… :P). If you are into counting, here are some of the good learning companions we’ve found, mostly in the library .. :)

**Chicka Chicka 1, 2, 3 by Bill Martin Jr., Michael Sampson, Lois Ehlert **

Source: Goodreads

“Chicka Chicka 1, 2, 3, will there be a place for me?”

It’s a simple story. Really. Numbers climbing up the apple tree, numbers falling down the tree.Yet, you’ll get to go from 1 to 100! We love spotting the big, colorful numbers and of course, _spoiler alert!!!_…. Zero the hero! ;)

Fish Eyes: A Book You Can Count On by Lois Ehlert

Something to touch, something to count. This book was great back when the big brother’s attention span was very, very short. His attention span wavered not long after he started if I just asked him to count out loud. But, once I asked him to touch the fish eyes while counting, he marched on! :D

Everything Goes: 123 Beep Beep Beep!: A Counting Book by Brian Biggs

Source: Goodreads

The big brother LOVES this book very much. What to say, it has cars, trucks, different kinds of cars… and different kinds of trucks (Ha! See the pattern?).

Everything Goes: In the Air by Brian Biggs

Source: Goodreads

We can’t resist any book with an I-Spy potential. Think of Where’s Wally series, but with numbers. Spot all the number from 1 to 100 spread all over the pages while you go on an airplane ride with Henry and his family… :) Try Everything Goes: On Land by Brian Biggs if you’re more into city theme.

100 Things  by Masayuki Sebe

Source: Goodreads

If not for my sweet cousin, we wouldn’t get to know about this book and the next book. Yup, we are the proud owners of this very cute book. I almost didn’t let the big brother touch this book. The illustrations are just so nice that it’ll definitely break my heart if I see any of the pages torn! It turns out that the big brother takes good care of it. Observe each character and you’ll laugh at their funny expressions (eeks.. one of them farted!) and captions (and it just said “I feel much better now”!!). There would also be some specific tasks in each page, like finding the mouse with red ribbon. And oh, see if you can spot the animal that came before and the one that follows! Loads of fun!

100 Animals on Parade! by Masayuki Sebe

Source: Goodreads

Again, this is where you’ll get to count from 1 to 100 more than once… :P Five times, in fact! All with different animals. Afraid that you’ll lose count? Don’t worry, you’ll find some of them with numbers so you don’t need to start again from the very beginning. But if you insist, why not… I know they’re just kawaii! And don’t forget to spot the ant, snail and ladybug in each page… ;)

Do share some of your favorite books, too! :)

item.title: A "Hole" New World
item.description:
I got a lot of spare tires… >_<

Eeeks.. don’t you dare poking my waist. Nope, I’m not referring that around my waist!

I mean, these small tires…

Spare Tires

Remember when I told you about how much my little ones love holes? The little brother obviously also adores the tire’s hole. I know I should have shown more gratitude that the little brother’s concentration, hand-eye coordination and fine motor skills are progressing well. Imagine all the muscles he uses to take off those tires from the big brother’s cars! But still, it gets on my nerves, when I’m the one summoned to find and collect all these tires… >_<”

Anyway, the recently acquired books only confirm their not-so-secret love affair.

What’s Wrong with My Hair by Satoshi Kitamura

We first borrowed this when nursing was still the little brother’s favorite pastime. We needed something to entertain the big brother. But, let’s just be frank, sometimes you just don’t want to read the same thing for the n-th time in the day. This book really came in handy then. The big brother could put himself in Lionel’s shoes as the lion tried out different hairstyles. All he had to do is put his face on the head-sized hole, find a mirror, and giggle - repeat as needed… :)

Peck, Peck, Peck by Lucy Cousins

Source: Goodreads

The fact that there are more than one copy of this book in the library only confirms how well-loved this book is. Both my husband and I borrowed this book, separately, around the same time, so, for a while, we ended up having 2 copies at home… :P As the little bird happily pecked, the little brother happily poked his finger through the finger-sized holes. The big brother, on the other hand, took it as a chance to play I Spy: I would read what the bird pecks and he would race me to find the object. Told you…It was great having 2 copies for 2 kids, after all… :P

item.title: Of Circles and Contrast
item.description:
As the big brother and I explore contrast - one of the principles in art - we learned about Sonia Delaunay. We looked at one of her works, Electric Prisms, and thought that we should made something similar to call our own… :)

We began with a treasure hunt to find various objects that are circles around the house, such as glass, coaster, coins, etc. and drew our different-sized circles.

Circles and More

Next, we colored our circles. The big brother chose oil pastel and so we used the oil pastel to learn about different shades for the contrast.

Contrast!

Tempted to make one, too? Oh, please do! And oh, don’t forget to sign with a smiley face… :)

Signed by Yours Truly

Done!

In case you’re wondering where the little brother was when we did this activity, lo and behold… our little clown, busy entertaining us from the opposite chair… :P

Circles on My Nose

Enjoy your treasure hunt ;)

item.title: On Chinese New Year
item.description:
It’s Chinese New Year and frankly, none of us here is a real expert in the celebration. Every year, I’m just glad to learn that we should be putting our brooms and brushes away. No home cleaning on New Year. Great. I’m relieved from all my housekeeping duty!

But, hey, maybe this New Year, we should go beyond that. So, we went to borrow our “manual” from the library.

Source: Goodreads

The big brother said he likes this story about a family preparing for the New Year: the Chinese decoration, dumplings, firecrackers and the like. Sounds like a great manual? There is only one problem, though: it’s already Chinese New Year! Oh well, let’s just say we’ve got ourselves the manual to prepare for the next Chinese New Year… Yup, we’re that excited and early… ;)

The Lion Dancers and the Drummer

Happy Chinese New Year!

item.title: To School, to School!
item.description:
This Chinese New Year, the School of Fun gets on our horse and take tiny steps to this door.

The Door

Yup, to school, to the big brother’s school, we go! ;)

The school needed a volunteer to conduct a Chinese New Year related art and craft session and we put our hand up. We searched high and low for the perfect activity and thanks to Google, we found just the right one… :)

Hold Your Horses!

Of course, it wouldn’t be fun without a storytelling session. We thought of sharing the ancient folk story about the 12 animals in Chinese zodiac cycle. But really, there is nothing horsey about it. The rat steals the limelight… :P

We need a book with a horse in this Year of the Horse. A mighty horse would be great. A magic horse? Even better! And this Chinese New Year, I couldn’t think of any other book with that to offer than The Magic Horse of Han Gan.

Source: Goodreads

Five years and 2 kids later, I think my storytelling skill has much improved… _yayy!!_ Nobody dozed off, even when it was as early as 8 AM. There I was, mesmerized by the beauty of this wide eyed wonder as these kids, my adorable audience, sat down and listened about how Han Gan painted the most powerful horse. Twice!

Wide Eyed Wonder

Next, the kids were introduced to their “magic wands” to make their own magic horses: paint brushes, cotton buds, skewers, toothpicks and … their fingers, of course!

Horse-Around Time!

Each kid chose her favorite magic wand and got busy right away. Many of them chose to do finger painting, but some did get creative with the back of their brushes and toothpicks.

Working Their Magic Wands

And, ladies and gentlemen, may I present to you… the Masterpiece!

Ready the Horses!

If you really want to spot the big brother’s, it’s on the last row, second from left. He said he wanted a cute horse, not a mighty one, so he drew a small one… ^_^”

Later that day, on the way home, the big brother asked if I would come and join him at school again next time. It really made my heart swell with joy. I know he enjoyed taking the assistant role while I conducted the first session (he only got to paint his horse on the second session). But when he asked me that question, I learned that he was proud to have me in his classroom. And the next day, when one of his friends asked the same question, I know I must have done something right somewhere… :’)

item.title: The Red Lanterns
item.description:
Never before have I used my stapler so much in a day…

The Worn Out Stapler

My stapler may be worn out. Yet, 60+ red envelopes later… I think we’re all smiles.

The Simplest One

The Tricky One

The Ball

The UFO

The view from below is great…

Mesmerizing Twirl

I guess I have just found another good reason to simply lie down and enjoy the view. These lanterns aren’t going to stay here for long anyway… They’re heading to the big brother’s school tomorrow!!! _sigh_

item.title: The Little Fair Gentlemen
item.description:
It turns out that this parenting-a-5-year-old gig is just … well, mysteriously different.

On good days

One moment, he might be helping his little brother unravel the mystery of how to properly wear socks, patiently explaining each step. Yup, just like a grown-up. Yet, in another, he claimed that lining his cars in the fridge was the coolest thing to do (Look at the cars’ windows, Mommy!). Yeah, our fridge, his carpark… >_<

There are days when you see a fine young gentleman, polite and all. This little fair gentleman held the door open for an old woman. Even when he was not asked to. Yet, in a split second, he was back running and screaming like a silly, uhm, …. 5-year-old boy.

And yes, there are days when you get to hear “please”, “sorry” and “thank you” more often than “It’s not fair!” or “Noooo!!!”. Or “But I want that… “ Other days seem to need more hard work, though…

I must say that those good days owe much to those days of reading these books. Funny how they all include dinosaurs … :P

How Do Dinosaurs… ? by Jane Yolen and Mark Teague

There are quite a number in this series. We read these board books much when the big brother was smaller and very much into dinosaurs. He got to enjoy seeing different kids of dinosaurs, while I got to see that he learns “the right thing”. Ha! :D

 Dinosaurs Don’t, Dinosaurs Do by Steve Björkman

Source: Goodreads

This book recently went home from the library with us after the little brother chanced upon it. I guess it’s just hard to resist checking out the book when you see such nice illustration! A good book to learn how to read as well as to make friends … :)

Suppose You Meet a Dinosaur: A First Book of Manners by Judy Sierra

We borrowed and read this book countless time! The first time we read it, the 3-year-old big brother thought he was cool when he could guess what the dinosaur or the girl would say each time. He thought he could read! We laughed a lot whenever we read this although I always feel like skipping the part when the dinosaur refused a snack as she was worried about her weight… ^_^” Not that easy to explain to kids, eh?!

I wish you luck in finding these books in the library. We may still be hogging them… _grinz_

item.title: Blue Bear: Over and Out!
item.description:
The three kings are almost here, and I have yet to conclude the adventure of Blue Bear… _gasp!_

As we crossed the last week of Advent, there were simply so many other things to take picture of that we actually forgot taking pictures of Blue Bear… ouch!

Four Candles on a Wreath: Done!

The big brother took over the duty of hiding Blue Bear on the weekend and so, Blue Bear literally went places.

On Monday, Blue Bear got busy with the wrapping paper. So was the Big Brother, of course… :)

Cut and Stick

And finally, on Tuesday night, Blue Bear was buried under all the torn and crumpled wrapping paper, while the Big Brother feasted on all his new toys… :P

Blue Bear, though dearly missed, is now officially on holiday… :)

Merry Christmas and Happy New Year to all!

This Year's Nativity Scene

Happy Christmas!

item.title: Blue Bear and the Mushy Marshmallows
item.description:
Christmas is drawing nigh. And how will we deal with it?

We can approach it frantically, trying to strike out each and every thing in our list.

On the Table

Or we can… keep calm, sit down and enjoy…

Mushy!

There will be marshmallow squashed on the table (and somebody trying to lick it off… >_<).

Somebody will eventually spill some hot chocolate, leaving stains (hopefully, not permanent!) on your favorite tablecloth.

There will be annoying sticky marshmallows on those small T-shirts.

But that’s okay… stay calm.

Yumm-o!

It’s time to make memories that last a lifetime… :)

item.title: Blue Bear: Make Flowers
item.description:
Check out what Blue Bear was found with last Thursday!

Be Mine...

Yup, making flowers we would… simply because cutting felt scraps is therapeutic. Especially for the hyped-up in this season of rush… :P

What we had:

  1. Felt scraps

  2. Scissors

  3. Chopsticks

  4. String

Let the Fun Begin!

This is one great way to get rid of those felt scraps. The big brother helped to cut into smaller strips. No, it doesn’t need to be perfectly of the same size. Imperfection is beauty… :)

Tied up with a string

Once you’ve got them all tied up with a string, get a chopstick to poke through your pom pom, like a stem.

Make one. Or two. As many as you like. With as many colors you could think of.

Put them in a jar, if you like.

In a Jar

Sit down and admire… or stand…

Look Great from Above

They make great Christmas decoration, too…

On a Tree
